description: FNCE 235 is a rigorous study of fixed income securities, including default-free bonds, floating rate notes, and corporate bonds. Closely related financial instruments such as forwards and futures on fixed income securities, bond options, and interest rate swaps are also examined. In addition to analyzing specific types of fixed income securities, there will be an examination of the tools used in bond portfolio management.
name: FIXED INCOME SECURITIES

values.comments:
This course is a study of the valuation of a wide variety of fixed income securities and their derivatives. The goal of this class is to provide analytic tools used in bond portfolio and interest rate risk management. 

The majority of students enjoyed this course, but found it to be “challenging.” Some students commented that the course covered topics more qualitatively than they would have preferred. 

Most students favored Professor Dieckman, commenting specifically on his breadth of knowledge pertaining to the course and care for the students. Some also said that he did a great job of “stimulating student interest.” A select few commented on a slight disconnect between the course pack provided for the course and Professor Dieckman’s lectures. 

Grading is based on two midterm exams, a final project, and problem sets. Prerequisites are FNCE101 and STAT10. Though this course is open to both Wharton freshmen and upperclassmen, students emphasized the importance of the prerequisites in understanding the course material.
